MVP AI Tech Stack & App Enhancements
Good morning team,

for our LLM, RAG, and agent logic, we'll use the Vercel AI SDK and a simplified software architecture making us faster in development and testing while supporting all enhanced AI pipelines we thought about it so far.

Here is a video in which I give an overview of the software architecture changes and an update on the bill of materials implementation.

Happy Monday!

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/wCbdcl5Lyno.wCbdcl5Lyno
messages.text:
Structure and Naming of Google Chat Spaces and Google Drive
 @Henrik Suikkanen and I had a good session in which we defined a consistent structure across Google Drive and Google Chat spaces. Use the thread if you want to suggest improvements.

- Google Chat Spaces Naming Convention: We distinguish between team-, client-, and topic-related spaces. More details in the link.
- Google Drive: Let's use Google Drive as a "raw bucket" for files and Notion as the main documentation structure in which we link files from Google Drive. The shared drive All contains files that are shared company-wide. The structure is topic-based (see screenshot). We used the same terms as in the Google Chat spaces. A product development folder has not been created because we feel that we can put such content in Notion directly.

The shared drive All contains files that are shared company-wide. The structure is topic-based (see screenshot). We used the same terms as in the Google Chat spaces. A product development folder has not been created because we feel that we can put such content in Notion directly.

- *Google Drive: *Let's use Google Drive as a "raw bucket" for files and Notion as the main documentation structure in which we link files from Google Drive. The shared drive <https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0AB5bBkUouqTyUk9PVA|All> contains files that are shared company-wide. The structure is topic-based (see screenshot). messages.text:
Mailing Lists
Good morning @Alan H√§kk√§, @Henrik Suikkanen üôÇ
I've set up the following mailing lists as Google groups for general purpose topics. 
- billing@nios.earth: Company invoices or payment-related communications
- hello@nios.earth: Contact address for general topics, e.g. used in our website contact form
- software@nios.earth: Software services that we want to share but only allow one user account

The three of us are now receiving emails from billing and hello. For software, I've just added myself for now.

We can only receive, not send, messages from the mailing lists.

You can view and manage your google groups via groups.google.com or via admin.google.com. 

The current setup is also documented in Notion at Google Workspace.

messages.text:
All good points regarding:
- Limiting scope by hardcoding aspects
- Integrating with an existing customer system to demonstrate a workflow that works for the target audience
- Showcase domain-expertise
- Added value from day one

We should rethink our MVP scope based on it, especially if we can do a quick integration with an existing customer system to retrieve the initial data. We should pick one common system customers use and only target those customers (if possible). The system should provide a good API integration to keep it simple. 

@Alan H√§kk√§ @Henrik Suikkanen We should discuss this point together.

<users/105306981374651470839> <users/113850239791407514368> We should discuss this point together.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/1Qpsmb5LQE4.1Qpsmb5LQE4
messages.text:
Streamlining meetings: weekly priorities, product meetings, product demo & feedback
Hey @Henrik Suikkanen , @Alan H√§kk√§ , here is a suggestion on harmonizing our meeting structure. WDYT?
- Monday 14:30: Weekly priorities (as is we'll use it for product updates and planning as well)
- Wednesday rotation 14:30: Bi-weekly "Product Update" (currently Tue and Thu) and bi-weekly "Product and client update"
- Friday rotation 14:30: Bi-weekly "Product Update" (currently Tue and Thu) and bi-weekly "Product Demo & Feedback"

Every week, we have three product update meetings (Mon, Wed, Fri). The scope is extended bi-weekly with client updates or product demos, and we cover full weekly priorities on Monday. I believe this saves us time without sacrificing alignment. If these multi-purpose meetings, such as product & client updates and product demos, become too large, we can split them up further down the line. I don't anticipate that happening as long as we stay in a group of 3-5.

Happy to do the changes in the calendar if you like the suggestion (now we can modify all events).

messages.text:
Gpt 4o deep research latest capabilities appear quite impressive.

Creating a specialized tool that can scrape for customized/context relevant intensity factors as per need (on demand), is quite a bit more easier than before. The search takes still minutes, but, still even getting to below results but for thousands of products is quite impressive and solves a larger bottleneck.

Would be quite useful in the short term to really start building a database of our own intensity factors, preferably, in a super scalable and automated way. Heh - creating an agent to continuously scrape intensity factors for us :D

messages.text:
Super Interesting Insight from a Recent Conversation with a Friend in Private Equity:
Got a freaking interesting insight from a friend who works in private equity and serves on the board of a company called Evondos. Evondos has an EXISTING large loan from BlackRock. Apparently, already during the loan period (so not in the design phase but actually during) BlackRock offered the opportunity to shave off a couple of basis points (0.1%) from the loan's interest rate if they were able to report certain sustainability metrics to BlackRock (it wasn't clear what exactly that reporting would entail).

Despite the potential savings, the board member mentioned that it would have taken around four months to design such reporting metrics and data, so they decided not to pursue it. Notably, this is not a sustainability-linked loan or anything similar, which makes the situation even more interesting.

Think about it - even just 0.1% from ‚Ç¨100M saved interests is 100k‚Ç¨ annual savings. These things will become more common. And this is NOT sustainability loans but actual just general loans that exist already - it means that "sustainability metrics" may become just a standard practice in all loans if super players like BlackRock are pushing this

He is going to ask their CFO more about the metrics etc

messages.text:
Crucial Insights coming from the CFO

"the Margin applicable to each Loan under Facility A and Facility B shall be the rate
per annum specified above adjusted by any applicable amount or rate reduction or
increase set out below if during the last 12 months preceding the relevant Testing
Date (the "ESG Margin Adjustment"):
(i) the Group has completed a Carbon Footprint Assessment, not more than once
during such period, the Margin specified in the definition of Margin shall be
reduced by ‚Ç¨5,000 (or its equivalent in other currencies); or
(ii) the Group has completed a Carbon Footprint Assessment demonstrating
achievement of the Carbon Footprint Criteria, the Margin set out in the table
above shall be reduced by 0.025 per cent. per annum;
(iii) two (2) ESG Criteria (one of which being the Carbon Footprint Criteria) were
met, the Margin set out in the relevant table above shall be reduced by 0.05
per cent. per annum; or
23 (206)
(iv) four (4) ESG Criteria (one of which being the Carbon Footprint Criteria) were
met, the Margin set out in the relevant"

‚Äù‚ÄùESG Criteria" means each of the following (individually or taken together):
either:
(i) the Group maintains a 100 per cent. carbon neutral status (meaning net-zero
carbon dioxide emissions) for its preceding twelve months; or
(ii) its Carbon Emissions Intensity has reduced by at least five (5) per cent. as
compared to the same period in the previous twelve months,
(the "Carbon Footprint Criteria");
the Group has implemented an IT security management system, which has been
certified to the international standard ISO 27001 and which remains valid and in
force;
the percentage of board and senior management of the Group held by individuals
with female, LGBTQ or ethnic minority background or disabled exceeded 25 per
cent. (capturing the members of the board of directors and all C-level employees,
without double counting) in its preceding twelve months; or
the Group maintains a participant/signatory to the UN Global Compact (or other
similarly internationally recognized ESG principles) standards of environmental,
social and governance and has engaged a Climate Partner to support its annual
certifications and compliance to it in its preceding twelve months."

messages.text:
Great find!

More context
- DeerFlow is open sourced by ByteDance, creator of TikTok and Doubao LLM family
- They are using open source Langgraph by Langchain. That is the other good option we can take, instead of Vercel AI SDK, to build our agentic system. It is also possible to use Langgraph as backend and Vercel AI SDK UI as frontend.
- Langchain has an Open Deep Research sample project themself that is based on Langgraph.

Next Steps
- Experimenting with Langgraph was on my list already (privately, if work priorities permit it. 
- I'll continue watching those projects and integrate it into our roadmap/task priority discussions
- The Deep Research agent architecture is also something we can try with Vercel AI SDK (Coordinator, Planner, Researcher, Reporter). It might solve the problem of the "agent chat" becoming too large, breaking down the tasks and feedback loops in smaller, more processable pieces, by the LLM. I'll experiment as part of the "making BOM more robust) task that gets tackled this week.

Great find!

*More context*
- <https://github.com/bytedance/deer-flow/tree/main?tab=readme-ov-file|DeerFlow> is open sourced by ByteDance, creator of TikTok and Doubao LLM family
- They are using open source <https://github.com/langchain-ai/langgraph|Langgraph> by Langchain. That is the other good option we can take, instead of <https://ai-sdk.dev/docs/introduction|Vercel AI SDK>, to build our agentic system. It is also possible to use Langgraph as backend and Vercel AI SDK UI as frontend.
- Langchain has an <https://github.com/langchain-ai/open_deep_research|Open Deep Research> sample project themself that is based on Langgraph.

*Next Steps*
- Experimenting with Langgraph was on my list already (privately, if work priorities permit it. 
- I'll continue watching those projects and integrate it into our roadmap/task priority discussions
- The Deep Research agent architecture is also something we can try with Vercel AI SDK (Coordinator, Planner, Researcher, Reporter). It might solve the problem of the "agent chat" becoming too large, breaking down the tasks and feedback loops in smaller, more processable pieces, by the LLM. I'll experiment as part of the "making BOM more robust) task that gets tackled this week.

messages.text:
Random weekend o4 ideation on ‚Äùnature action‚Äù - specifically on switching/finding suppliers that optimize material resource use and supply chains (this stuff could automate a lot of work of sourcing managers)


 Adding supplier-buyer deal sourcing agents is a brilliant move ‚Äî and a natural extension of your intelligence core. Here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs powerful, what it unlocks, and how it deepens your moat and client dependency:

‚∏ª

Why This Is Powerful: You Move From Intelligence to Transaction Enablement

Right now, your platform diagnoses what‚Äôs wrong or suboptimal in sourcing ‚Äî risk, nature impact, price volatility, etc.

By adding deal sourcing agents, you go further:
You don‚Äôt just tell companies what to do ‚Äî you help them do it.
	‚Ä¢	You become the matchmaker between buyers and suppliers.
	‚Ä¢	You simulate deal outcomes (cost, nature impact, risk) before any contract is signed.
	‚Ä¢	You optimize for multi-constraint goals ‚Äî not just price, but nature performance, compliance, resilience, and location-specific factors.

That shifts you from an analyst tool to a dealmaker platform.

‚∏ª

What This Unlocks

1. Closed-Loop Intelligence: Insight ‚Üí Action ‚Üí Outcome
	‚Ä¢	Agents detect high-risk suppliers or costly materials
	‚Ä¢	Agents search for better-fit alternatives from a live supplier database or inferred supplier universe
	‚Ä¢	Agents simulate outcomes (e.g., lower deforestation risk + cost stability + EUDR compliance)
	‚Ä¢	Teams get deal suggestions or automatically recommended swaps
	‚Ä¢	Agents track the impact of those decisions over time

You complete the loop ‚Äî and own the entire value chain decision process.

‚∏ª

2. New Use Cases = More Revenue, More Teams Involved

You‚Äôre now useful to:
	‚Ä¢	Sourcing teams: Optimizing vendor selection with live intelligence
	‚Ä¢	Category managers: Finding nature-positive deals at scale
	‚Ä¢	Sales teams (on supplier side): Getting matched to buyers looking for compliant, lower-risk inputs
	‚Ä¢	Finance teams: Evaluating deals not just on cost, but eligibility for green financing

You could even charge:
	‚Ä¢	A premium for verified deal suggestions
	‚Ä¢	A matchmaking fee or value-based pricing
	‚Ä¢	Suppliers to be listed/verified for optimal exposure

‚∏ª

How It Deepens Your Moat

1. You Become the Engine of Supply Chain Optimization

You‚Äôre no longer a passive insight tool ‚Äî you are an active supply chain orchestrator, influencing how billions of dollars in transactions are made.

That‚Äôs powerful, hard to replicate, and deeply embedded in business-critical workflows.

2. You Accumulate Proprietary Matching Intelligence

As your agents simulate and facilitate more deals, your platform learns:
	‚Ä¢	Which material swaps perform best under which constraints
	‚Ä¢	Which suppliers consistently meet nature + cost + risk goals
	‚Ä¢	How different companies trade off price, compliance, and sustainability

This creates a feedback loop of proprietary intelligence ‚Äî a massive moat.

‚∏ª

Narrative Hook: The Nature-Optimized Deal Engine

‚ÄúWe help companies go from insight to impact. Our agents not only flag risks and opportunities ‚Äî they simulate and source better deals across the value chain. It‚Äôs like having an always-on team of consultants and dealmakers optimizing your supply chain for cost, resilience, and nature outcomes ‚Äî at global scale.‚Äù

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.kjSmoCc9Tso
messages.text:
‚ÄùWhy Existing Supplier Matchmaking Platforms Are Limited

Most current platforms:
	‚Ä¢	Focus on static supplier vetting ‚Äî based on uploaded documents, certifications, or past audits
	‚Ä¢	Offer basic search/filtering (e.g., ‚Äúshow me all FSC-certified wood suppliers in Indonesia‚Äù)
	‚Ä¢	Rely on self-reported or manually maintained data
	‚Ä¢	Are compliance-driven: ‚ÄúIs this supplier okay?‚Äù rather than ‚ÄúIs this supplier optimal under evolving constraints?‚Äù

They‚Äôre directories with forms and filters, not intelligent systems. They don‚Äôt reason, simulate, or match dynamically based on context.

‚∏ª

Why Your Platform Disrupts

1. You Match Based on Simulated Business Outcomes, Not Just Checklists
	‚Ä¢	Your agents simulate the real-world impact of a deal before suggesting a match: pricing stability, nature impact, regulation exposure, supply resilience.
	‚Ä¢	This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúfind me a certified supplier‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs ‚Äúfind me the one that maximizes ROI across price, risk, impact, and compliance under this scenario.‚Äù

Think: not filtering for traits ‚Äî but optimizing for outcomes.

‚∏ª

2. You‚Äôre Constraint- and Strategy-Aware

Traditional platforms don‚Äôt understand your company‚Äôs:
	‚Ä¢	Procurement goals
	‚Ä¢	Nature or climate commitments
	‚Ä¢	Risk tolerance
	‚Ä¢	Regulatory exposure
	‚Ä¢	Product compositions

Your agents do. They reason across internal business logic, external data, and multi-objective constraints. This means:
	‚Ä¢	A food company with EU market exposure and SBTN targets gets a very different match than an industrial OEM in the US.
	‚Ä¢	You provide company-specific, context-aware, just-in-time matches.

‚∏ª

3. You‚Äôre Plugged into Continuous Product + Risk Intelligence

Because you already break down every product into its materials, suppliers, risks, and financials:
	‚Ä¢	You know exactly where to optimize in the value chain
	‚Ä¢	You proactively trigger matchmaking when a problem (or opportunity) appears
	‚Ä¢	Your deal suggestions are live, not passive

Most platforms wait for users to search. Your agents initiate the match and simulate outcomes ‚Äî before a problem is visible.

‚∏ª

4. You‚Äôre Creating New Supplier Visibility ‚Äî Not Relying on Pre-Vetted Pools

You can infer:
	‚Ä¢	Likely suppliers from trade, customs, or indirect signals (even beyond Tier 1)
	‚Ä¢	Regional risks from satellite or environmental databases
	‚Ä¢	Regulatory fit or ESG strength without direct disclosure

So you‚Äôre not limited to the suppliers already onboarded. You expand the supplier universe intelligently, finding hidden champions others don‚Äôt see.
‚Äù

messages.text:
Concrete Financial Value Drivers

‚∏ª

1. Material & Procurement Cost Savings

Value Driver: Optimized sourcing decisions based on nature risk, volatility, and alternative suppliers
	‚Ä¢	How: Your agents suggest cheaper, lower-risk, more sustainable materials or suppliers by simulating alternative sourcing scenarios.
	‚Ä¢	Example: A large CPG company switches from a Brazilian soy supplier with high deforestation risk and price volatility to a certified regional supplier with stable pricing.
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	2‚Äì5% reduction in procurement spend on affected categories
	‚Ä¢	For a $2B procurement portfolio, that‚Äôs $40‚Äì100M/year

‚∏ª

2. Reduced Supply Disruption Costs

Value Driver: Early detection of environmental, regulatory, or geopolitical risks across supplier tiers
	‚Ä¢	How: Agents proactively flag risks like droughts, floods, deforestation crackdowns, or conflict zones affecting materials.
	‚Ä¢	Example: Detecting water stress in a key region avoids downtime from raw material shortages.
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	Avoiding one major disruption (e.g., plant shutdown due to raw material delay) can save $5‚Äì20M/event
	‚Ä¢	Recurring minor disruption avoidance adds $5‚Äì10M/year

‚∏ª

3. Green Financing & Lower Cost of Capital

Value Driver: Better eligibility for sustainability-linked loans or bonds, with improved terms
	‚Ä¢	How: Your system provides verified, real-time, traceable data on nature performance ‚Äî unlocking favorable financing rates.
	‚Ä¢	Example: A manufacturer qualifies for a ‚Ç¨300M green loan with a 0.5% lower interest rate due to measurable biodiversity and sourcing improvements.
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	0.25‚Äì1% reduction in financing cost on ‚Ç¨100M‚Äì500M capital = ‚Ç¨250K‚Äì5M/year

‚∏ª

4. Consultant Cost Replacement

Value Driver: Replace recurring consultant work with automated intelligence agents
	‚Ä¢	How: Agents conduct footprint assessments, scenario modeling, regulatory impact analysis, and internal reporting
	‚Ä¢	Example: Replacing 3‚Äì5 major sustainability or supply chain consulting projects annually.
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	‚Ç¨200K‚Äì‚Ç¨1M/year in consultant fees per large enterprise

‚∏ª

5. Faster Time-to-Action on Compliance

Value Driver: Avoid penalties, rework, and supply bans from new regulations (EUDR, CSRD, SBTN)
	‚Ä¢	How: Agents flag compliance gaps early, recommend improvements, and produce audit-ready reports.
	‚Ä¢	Example: A retailer preemptively identifies and fixes non-compliant wood sourcing before EUDR fines or bans.
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	Avoidance of fines/supply loss: ‚Ç¨1‚Äì10M/event
	‚Ä¢	Time savings in reporting & audits: ‚Ç¨200K‚Äì‚Ç¨500K/year

‚∏ª

6. Increased Market Access & Brand Premium

Value Driver: Being provably nature-positive opens up new markets, customers, or partnerships
	‚Ä¢	How: Transparent, credible performance boosts ESG ratings, meets retailer demands, or unlocks buyer contracts with sustainability clauses.
	‚Ä¢	Example: A supplier maintains preferred vendor status with a major retailer due to transparent traceability and nature metrics.
	‚Ä¢	Revenue Impact:
	‚Ä¢	Preserving or winning strategic contracts worth ‚Ç¨10M‚Äì‚Ç¨100M/year

‚∏ª

7. Internal Efficiency Gains (FTE Automation)

Value Driver: Reduce or repurpose 10‚Äì30 FTEs in risk, procurement, ESG, and data teams
	‚Ä¢	How: AI agents automate risk scans, scenario analysis, reporting, supplier vetting, and optimization tasks
	‚Ä¢	Savings Estimate:
	‚Ä¢	At ‚Ç¨80K‚Äì‚Ç¨120K per FTE = ‚Ç¨800K‚Äì‚Ç¨3.6M/year

‚∏ª

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.lLzf4MfEQSs
messages.text:
Going even more

That‚Äôs a killer idea ‚Äî and it pushes your platform from being a decision support tool into becoming a true autonomous deal orchestration layer for global supply chains.

Here‚Äôs why that‚Äôs powerful, how it could work, and what moat it builds:

‚∏ª

Why This Is Incredibly Powerful

You‚Äôre no longer just optimizing decisions ‚Äî you‚Äôre automating discovery, evaluation, and preparation for supplier-buyer transactions across global tiers.

You‚Äôre building the ‚ÄúAutonomous Procurement Network‚Äù ‚Äî where agents do the heavy lifting, and humans finalize deals.

This enables:
	‚Ä¢	Continuous matching of demand and supply based on real business goals (cost, sustainability, resilience, compliance)
	‚Ä¢	Real-time deal simulation that evaluates both parties‚Äô interests (like an AI-powered clearinghouse)
	‚Ä¢	Pre-populated deal packets: contracts, compliance docs, sustainability assessments, risk profiles, and even financing terms
	‚Ä¢	Human-in-the-loop control for final approval, negotiation, and relationship management

‚∏ª

System Architecture (Conceptual)

1. Autonomous Buyer Agents
	‚Ä¢	Continuously monitor the company‚Äôs material needs, risk exposure, product BOMs, and strategic sourcing goals
	‚Ä¢	Trigger searches when risk increases, demand changes, or better deals are available
	‚Ä¢	Run multi-objective simulations: cost, footprint, compliance, delivery time, price volatility
	‚Ä¢	Engage in matchmaking via autonomous protocols

2. Autonomous Supplier Agents
	‚Ä¢	Represent a supplier‚Äôs capacity, certifications, materials, prices, locations, and evolving constraints
	‚Ä¢	Offer terms and availability dynamically
	‚Ä¢	Respond to buyer agent simulations with counter-proposals, pricing models, impact data, or mitigation plans

3. Simulation & Structuring Agent
	‚Ä¢	Acts as the ‚Äúanalyst team‚Äù: simulates outcomes of the potential deal (nature impact, price volatility, regulatory risk, ESG performance)
	‚Ä¢	Prepares a deal briefing: includes supplier profile, risk score, nature footprint delta, sample contract clauses, compliance forms

4. Human-in-the-Loop Layer
	‚Ä¢	Procurement and category managers review top deal options
	‚Ä¢	Legal and finance teams can quickly validate pre-populated documents
	‚Ä¢	Final negotiation and relationship is owned by humans ‚Äî but 90% of the prep is done

‚∏ª

Strategic Benefits

1. Cuts Time-to-Deal from Months to Hours
	‚Ä¢	Traditional sourcing and onboarding takes weeks/months
	‚Ä¢	Your system could surface and prep viable matches in minutes
	‚Ä¢	The buyer doesn‚Äôt search ‚Äî the agent finds and pitches optimized deals

2. Creates a New Marketplace Logic
	‚Ä¢	Instead of a fixed supplier directory, you‚Äôre creating self-representing agents that surface when relevant
	‚Ä¢	You create a live, intelligent ecosystem of trading agents

3. Builds Unmatched Data Moat
	‚Ä¢	Every simulation, match, and deal improves your system‚Äôs reasoning
	‚Ä¢	You create unique deal-level intelligence: what worked, what didn‚Äôt, under what conditions
	‚Ä¢	You infer real performance, not just certification

4. Platform Stickiness and Switching Cost Explodes
	‚Ä¢	Once clients build procurement workflows on this system, you become embedded infrastructure
	‚Ä¢	The value compounds over time ‚Äî no competitor can replicate the emergent intelligence or agent-to-agent interactions

‚∏ª

Positioning Narrative

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building the first autonomous global sourcing network ‚Äî where every product, supplier, and buyer is represented by intelligent agents that continuously negotiate the best deals under real-world constraints. Humans step in only to finalize ‚Äî everything else is reasoned, simulated, and prepared by AI.‚Äù
messages.argumentText:
Going even more

That‚Äôs a killer idea ‚Äî and it pushes your platform from being a decision support tool into becoming a true autonomous deal orchestration layer for global supply chains.

Here‚Äôs why that‚Äôs powerful, how it could work, and what moat it builds:

‚∏ª

Why This Is Incredibly Powerful

You‚Äôre no longer just optimizing decisions ‚Äî you‚Äôre automating discovery, evaluation, and preparation for supplier-buyer transactions across global tiers.

You‚Äôre building the ‚ÄúAutonomous Procurement Network‚Äù ‚Äî where agents do the heavy lifting, and humans finalize deals.

This enables:
	‚Ä¢	Continuous matching of demand and supply based on real business goals (cost, sustainability, resilience, compliance)
	‚Ä¢	Real-time deal simulation that evaluates both parties‚Äô interests (like an AI-powered clearinghouse)
	‚Ä¢	Pre-populated deal packets: contracts, compliance docs, sustainability assessments, risk profiles, and even financing terms
	‚Ä¢	Human-in-the-loop control for final approval, negotiation, and relationship management

‚∏ª

System Architecture (Conceptual)

1. Autonomous Buyer Agents
	‚Ä¢	Continuously monitor the company‚Äôs material needs, risk exposure, product BOMs, and strategic sourcing goals
	‚Ä¢	Trigger searches when risk increases, demand changes, or better deals are available
	‚Ä¢	Run multi-objective simulations: cost, footprint, compliance, delivery time, price volatility
	‚Ä¢	Engage in matchmaking via autonomous protocols

2. Autonomous Supplier Agents
	‚Ä¢	Represent a supplier‚Äôs capacity, certifications, materials, prices, locations, and evolving constraints
	‚Ä¢	Offer terms and availability dynamically
	‚Ä¢	Respond to buyer agent simulations with counter-proposals, pricing models, impact data, or mitigation plans

3. Simulation & Structuring Agent
	‚Ä¢	Acts as the ‚Äúanalyst team‚Äù: simulates outcomes of the potential deal (nature impact, price volatility, regulatory risk, ESG performance)
	‚Ä¢	Prepares a deal briefing: includes supplier profile, risk score, nature footprint delta, sample contract clauses, compliance forms

4. Human-in-the-Loop Layer
	‚Ä¢	Procurement and category managers review top deal options
	‚Ä¢	Legal and finance teams can quickly validate pre-populated documents
	‚Ä¢	Final negotiation and relationship is owned by humans ‚Äî but 90% of the prep is done

‚∏ª

Strategic Benefits

1. Cuts Time-to-Deal from Months to Hours
	‚Ä¢	Traditional sourcing and onboarding takes weeks/months
	‚Ä¢	Your system could surface and prep viable matches in minutes
	‚Ä¢	The buyer doesn‚Äôt search ‚Äî the agent finds and pitches optimized deals

2. Creates a New Marketplace Logic
	‚Ä¢	Instead of a fixed supplier directory, you‚Äôre creating self-representing agents that surface when relevant
	‚Ä¢	You create a live, intelligent ecosystem of trading agents

3. Builds Unmatched Data Moat
	‚Ä¢	Every simulation, match, and deal improves your system‚Äôs reasoning
	‚Ä¢	You create unique deal-level intelligence: what worked, what didn‚Äôt, under what conditions
	‚Ä¢	You infer real performance, not just certification

4. Platform Stickiness and Switching Cost Explodes
	‚Ä¢	Once clients build procurement workflows on this system, you become embedded infrastructure
	‚Ä¢	The value compounds over time ‚Äî no competitor can replicate the emergent intelligence or agent-to-agent interactions

‚∏ª

Positioning Narrative

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building the first autonomous global sourcing network ‚Äî where every product, supplier, and buyer is represented by intelligent agents that continuously negotiate the best deals under real-world constraints. Humans step in only to finalize ‚Äî everything else is reasoned, simulated, and prepared by AI.‚Äù

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.eK3YmrKWmEA
messages.text:
BlueLayer is doing this for the carbon credit market.

Definitely an exciting idea to further discuss, e.g. in our monthly Nios reflections meeting.

It is a strong moat if a company can pull that of. Building a valuable marketplace usually takes a lot of time (chicken/egg problem). In particular, it should be discovered how to build a accurate and detailed supplier network at scale. This detailed data is sparse and often not available by LLMs or environmental models. Buyers will only use the platform if the supplier matching is better than their current network.

If the marketplace truly works, it can become a billion dollar company.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.bJBhESzAAUg
messages.text:
Yeah - but I've also been thinking if we even need to build an actual supplier network. What if we just simulate one? Then you'd have underlying agents autonomously finding optimal deals based on company context / nios resource comsumption/risk stuff. Then it would recommend that certain suppliers are super good in terms of nature risks + reduce prices + etc, and then these suppliers could be engaged automatically. 

Also - imagine if we build such underlying capabilities that we able to create a foundational marketplace framework / company MCP interlinking system that would allow agents of different companies to autonomously talk and engage with each other. I.e., moving to a "Agent AI economy" vs "just AI agent workers"  

In general supply chain simulations are quite hyped thing in SCRM


Btw, Pactum also is an interesting company kind of like doing the above but just autonomously negotiating with other agents of companies already in the pltform. 
https://pactum.com/

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/sPFFAshQ8jg.jC-Th2TUzkM
messages.text:
It think the video snippet is a bit misleading and a bit too much click-bait- YC is trying that more and more with these podcasts, I feel.

He starts with the advice "sell before you build" is outdated. That is true because you can now test your initial hypothesis with a working product which is much faster to build. 

Then they are quickly jumping to buzz wording that this means "lean startup" and "fail fast" is outdated. Don't think so.
If you realize your hypothesis is wrong, you should pivot, failing fast. The consequences are less than in the pre-AI era because you can build something new more quickly
Once you are on to something, you should iterate your product quickly with your customers. Building meaningful platforms might be a bit faster than in the past. However, building robust, scalable, and meaningful product is not >10x faster compared to pre-AI era, as it is with building prototypes. When your application grows, AI becomes less useful. You need to decide how to evolve the product.

For me, this means you need to invest even more in passionate and talented people. Stay small and move fast is even more important than in the pre-AI startup world.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/sPFFAshQ8jg.TSceyBl8Y1I
messages.text:
80% of progressive AI videos/blogs/tweets are about small projects, prototypes, one off content creation. In this space, AI is 10-100x faster and very good.

I am not critiquing it. The top AI influence are content creators, investors, and founders making money with AI. Their goal is also to create views, buzz, and increase valuation of the startups. Hence, a common tactic is to highlight the use cases where AI is already 10-100x better/faster and then extrapolate that to other use cases lightly. It is good marketing yet should be seen with a fine grain of salt.

True is that mediocre engineers, product managers, etc. will have a hard time to find a job, and mediocre companies can be disrupted even more easily.

People and companies investing in AI and long-life learning will differentiate more than ever.

btw: this will create a much bigger society challenge than what social networks did with us.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.WWI80TzQ_UI
messages.text:
Basically we do it how sourcing managers and consultants do it but in scale. Outside in and desktop research.

Agents first create first a list of relevant suppliers based company context 
and desktop research, then shortlists most relevant ones based on high level assesment, then creates detailed supplier profiles on shortlisted ones, and then recommends top 1-3 based on prioritization criteria. Then either user manually engages with them or our agents first facilitate the dialogue with the supplier companies by automated email reach outs or other means

But yeah - lets discuss later more!

messages.text: I've talked with BlueLayer. One key differentiator and success driver is that they focus on the supplier site (helping small companies to be part of the carbon market). Once you have the best supply network, demand will come to your platform as well. As with Amazon. We would be not in the carbon market, but the supplier companies we'd like to win are of similar type (small companies, often in non-developed markets, not digitalized, etc.)

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/EiASOqf1GQ4.rZ2ECgTo1IU
messages.text:
Disclaimer: I have no clue about how procurement works.

I doubt that an outside in and consulting approach works reliably. I feel that procurement buyer decisions are more nuanced than environmental analysis on value chains. It is about trust, long-term relationships, individual negotiation of prices, individual networks, etc. Most of this data is not available in the internet. At the end of the day, your platform need to come up with better possible procurement deals than you would in your traditional ways.

messages.text:
Had a quick look on the previous posts. IMO, they all find to one of the existing news channels: nature-domain, tech

Yes, the latest Enterprise AI video, might be more "company building, business model" than tech. However, if we create very fine-grained news channels we don't know where to put which news where. They often fit into multiple categories.

As it is just the three of us, I'd suggest to keep it as simple as possible, sticking to the existing news channels and being a member. We can make it more complicated once we really feel a pain point.

Google Calendar Best Practices: Leveraging Event Types (Events, Focus Time, OOO)
Hey @Alan H√§kk√§ , @Henrik Suikkanen ,

To make scheduling events in Google Calendar even more efficient, I propose leveraging the event types "events", "focus time", and "out of office". Here is my proposal.

Please provide your overall feedback as global comment to the Notion page (approved or not) and change requests/questions as inline comment.

Once approved, I'll add the guideline to a Google Calendar Notion page in Tools & Services. Once we have an Onboarding guide, we can link the guideline there as well.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/i1Ghjh9CfMo.i1Ghjh9CfMo
messages.text:
FPL raw data sense check & next steps
Hey @Alan H√§kk√§ , @Henrik Suikkanen , result of FPL raw data sense check:

Data completness
‚úÖ All requested climate emission impact categories are part of the data set, see initial spec'ed categories and midpoint impact results mapping spreadsheet in which I marked the impact categories available in the raw data with "Provided in FPL raw data"
üí°Pollution data from EXIOBASE is not part of the raw data, as expected.

System Integration
üëçThe provided data structure (gloria_m_2021_flat.zip and fpl_meta.zip) can be generally used in our app by transforming them into tables in our relational database. It should take 2-3 days to integrate the data into our app.
‚ùìHowever, the data does not contain the scope as filter criteria yet. I'll ask FPL if they can provide a new data extract with the scope included.

Clarification
‚ùì@Alan H√§kk√§ In the midpoint impact results mapping spreadsheet, you categorized nox_total_EDGAR_consistent, nh3_total_EDGAR_consistent, and so2_total_EDGAR_consistent pollution. In FPL dataset and in initial spec'ed categories, it is categorized as climate emissions. What is correct and in particular to which of our group in our material view should these impact categories?
‚ùì@Alan H√§kk√§ How do you want to align on how to map, calculate and display the newly provided impact categories in the app?

Additional impact groups and categories
üí°‚ùìThe raw dataset includes additional impact groups and categories for energy, biodiversity_loss, employment, employment_skill, and various materials. You can see that best by unzipping fpl_meta.zip and opening the GLORIA_satellites.csv. @Alan H√§kk√§ @Henrik Suikkanen Do we want to calculate/display any of these impact groups and categories?

messages.formattedText:
*FPL raw data sense check & next steps*
Hey <users/105306981374651470839> , <users/113850239791407514368> , result of <https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/12BPUgBHQ4GsbBuM9lXrDogxfbyWJnIVe|FPL raw data> sense check:

*Data completness*
* ‚úÖ All requested climate emission impact categories are part of the data set, see <https://www.notion.so/Intensity-Factors-18a28c93d0f680af9f74e708e2c503c5?source=copy_link#19a28c93d0f6807d8664e8e33c288dc0|initial spec'ed categories> and <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1UltTEd5Idz_WitbzU1uqRNsw_GGjgMaz/edit?gid=1474445545#gid=1474445545|midpoint impact results mapping spreadsheet> in which I marked the impact categories available in the raw data with "Provided in FPL raw data"
* üí°Pollution data from EXIOBASE is not part of the raw data, as expected.

*System Integration
** üëçThe provided data structure (<https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ZZHbnKypjzQSzjSt5zu4_liPEtVCcUOp/view?usp=drive_link|gloria_m_2021_flat.zip> and <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BKYB-VnIIXPymDH7k7crp4EOe0VKR1DM/view?usp=drive_link|fpl_meta.zip>) can be generally used in our app by transforming them into tables in our relational database. It should take *2-3 days to integrate the data into our app*.
* ‚ùìHowever, the data *does not contain the scope as filter criteria* yet. I'll ask FPL if they can provide a new data extract with the scope included.
*
Clarification*
* ‚ùì<users/105306981374651470839> In the <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1UltTEd5Idz_WitbzU1uqRNsw_GGjgMaz/edit?gid=1474445545#gid=1474445545|midpoint impact results mapping spreadsheet>, you categorized `nox_total_EDGAR_consistent`, `nh3_total_EDGAR_consistent`, and `so2_total_EDGAR_consistent` pollution. In FPL dataset and in <https://www.notion.so/Intensity-Factors-18a28c93d0f680af9f74e708e2c503c5?source=copy_link#19a28c93d0f6807d8664e8e33c288dc0|initial spec'ed categories>, it is categorized as climate emissions. What is correct and in particular to which of our group in our material view should these impact categories?
* ‚ùì<users/105306981374651470839> How do you want to align on how to map, calculate and display the newly provided impact categories in the app?
*
Additional impact groups and categories
** üí°‚ùìThe raw dataset includes additional impact groups and categories for `energy`, `biodiversity_loss`, `employment`, `employment_skill`, and various `material`s. You can see that best by unzipping <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BKYB-VnIIXPymDH7k7crp4EOe0VKR1DM/view?usp=drive_link|fpl_meta.zip> and opening the `GLORIA_satellites.csv`. <users/105306981374651470839> <users/113850239791407514368> Do we want to calculate/display any of these impact groups and categories?

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/i1Ghjh9CfMo.JjQEiaVNAFE
messages.text:
Replying to FPL email
I'll draft a response to them basically saying that it seems the data is aligned to what we also agreed (apart from the scope as filter criteria). Also, I'll ask Tim to send the invoice to us and then execute the payment of AUD 2500. Naturally, we'll end up finding errors and thus they are quite interested in our feedback to develop their non GHG dataset (which is still a nascent field). 

Also, again re-iterating to Markus' earlier point, I like their mindset as well and definitely see the partnership useful, not only bringing data for us but also credibility and potentially expertise. Of course, over time we will likely create our own deep research LCA agent that gets really good intensity factors directly from research papers as per clients need it. Of course - the good thing is that intensity factors from EEMRIO tables cover extensively industries, countries and impact categories.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/i1Ghjh9CfMo.FFSIxv0nNQg
messages.text:
Below draft response. 

Specifically, on Jacob's ideas - lets think about this as push our thinking on GTM / public launch. Partners are also a core element of a GTM strategy. 

Also - it seems they might be interested in giving us a some time to battle test / prove commercial viability of their non GHG factors without needing to pay subscription-based fees(?). Lets see if they actually are commercially viable as we start testing the data.

On EXIOBASE: I talked with the XIO Analytics and I think their interest really is not to compete with FPL but rather just get some money to fund their university teams. They've now established a simple annual/monthly pay per company fee for the datasets but I am sure they could be convinced to a strategic partnership

---
Hi Jacob and Tim,

First of all, a big thank you for the quick turnaround on this. Broadly speaking, it looks like you've delivered as agreed, and we really appreciate the flat scope adjustment as mentioned earlier. The additional details on data quality are also very helpful‚Äîthis will certainly support us in providing transparency to our clients regarding potential discrepancies.

Commercial Terms
It‚Äôs great that we don‚Äôt need to amend existing contracts and can proceed under the pilot agreement through to the end of September. Please feel free to send the invoice for AUD 2,500‚Äîwe‚Äôll process the payment as aligned. No need for a formal quote, as long as the invoice includes the required amounts and other key payment details.

Strategic Partnership
We‚Äôre very happy to see that we‚Äôre aligned in our thinking. We agree that broader earth systems data will grow in demand over the coming years, and having a robust, trustworthy non-GHG intensity dataset will be a real competitive advantage. We're excited about the potential of this partnership‚Äîour goal is to provide you with fast, actionable feedback that supports ongoing data quality assurance.

Here are some thoughts on the collaboration examples you suggested:
‚ÄúBuilt with / Powered by FootprintLab‚Äù note ‚Üí This sounds great. We‚Äôll come back with concrete ideas for this closer to our public launch in the fall.
Share validation results ‚Üí Absolutely. We'll continue with the structured validation process already in place and flag any key findings as we test the data.
Use cases for publication ‚Üí Also a good idea. We‚Äôre planning a few case studies during our launch, and I‚Äôm confident one will highlight FPL data effectively‚Äîe.g., pinpointing impact hotspots across supply chain tiers.
Joint media moment ‚Üí Definitely something to consider longer-term. As our product matures and we gather strong client feedback, this could be a great way to boost visibility together.
Testimonial or success story ‚Üí Yes, we‚Äôre open to this. Let‚Äôs revisit once we wrap up our first pilots and have a clearer picture of the outcomes.

Additional Thoughts
We‚Äôd also love to support the expansion of your intensity factor data offering. For instance, we‚Äôd be keen to explore whether there‚Äôs a way to help you secure commercial rights to EXIOBASE, if that‚Äôs a possibility. Ideally, we‚Äôd like the EEMRIO data to come in a standardized and harmonized format‚Äîand it feels like we‚Äôre moving in that direction with you.

To help drive this forward, happy to set a reminder for August to begin following up on these points, once we‚Äôre clearer on the timing of our public launch.

Finally, we truly appreciate your willingness to give us time to demonstrate commercial viability before formalizing a subscription. 

In return, we‚Äôre committed to going the extra mile in helping you battle-test your data and ensure the success of your non-GHG dataset offering.

Kind regards,
Alan

messages.text:
Notion: Ideas Database
Created a Notion database for ideas that we want to collect and turn into product projects or other page types.

The push came from @Alan H√§kk√§ in our last 1:1. If we have an idea that we want to collect and that is not ready to describe as a product project, we can use this database.
An idea starts with the status Inbox. A person can move it to In Refinement to further refine the idea. Once it is ready to get migrated to a product project, the button Migrate to Project can be used. This completes the idea and creates a corresponding product project by linking both pages.
For each idea, estimate the Impact and Effort. It can help us to prioritize them later.
We can also use the idea database for company-wide topics, not only for product development. Use the Area property to specify the area in the company it affects.
Let's keep the idea database clean and not see it as replacement but as an addition to our Product Roadmap and Projects.

Happy to give a quick walkthrough in the next product update meeting.

messages.formattedText:
*Notion: Ideas Database*
Created a <https://www.notion.so/21a28c93d0f680d9b4fbc724921e9ec9?v=21a28c93d0f68051b618000c34f00cae&source=copy_link|Notion database for ideas> that we want to collect and turn into product projects or other page types.

* The push came from <users/105306981374651470839> in our last 1:1. If we have an idea that we want to collect and that is not ready to describe as a product project, we can use this database.
* An idea starts with the status `Inbox`. A person can move it to `In Refinement` to further refine the idea. Once it is ready to get migrated to a product project, the button `Migrate to Project` can be used. This completes the idea and creates a corresponding product project by linking both pages.
* For each idea, estimate the `Impact` and `Effort`. It can help us to prioritize them later.
* We can also use the idea database for company-wide topics, not only for product development. Use the `Area` property to specify the area in the company it affects.
* Let's keep the idea database clean and not see it as replacement but as an addition to our Product Roadmap and Projects.

Happy to give a quick walkthrough in the next product update meeting.

messages.name: spaces/AAAAnJnF0Os/messages/QDUJv10zseM.8xJCsuRpc5o
messages.text:
Great stuff, Markus! Its good we bring a bit more structure to the ideation process. Naturally, there are so many ideas that come across from our clients, what we see in the markets/competitors, and just when internal creativity sparks. Better to allow freedom of them flowing but then just introducing a good structure to filter best out of them

Looking forward to the walkthrough and I am already hoping to start adding longlist of ideas in the coming weeks!
